The combination of strong methanol adsorption and hindered intermediate migration results in localized carbon deposition, accelerating catalyst deactivation and reducing its TOS to 480 min, the shortest among the modified catalysts. In contrast, the sequential acid-base etched catalyst, SP34-AB, exhibits the lowest RCoke of 0.12 mg gcat −1 min−1, contributing to its significantly prolonged lifetime of 840 min. Although its total coke content (10.4 %) is slightly higher than that of SP34-A, the lower rate of coke formation suggests that coke precursors are more effectively dispersed and mitigated due to improved diffusion efficiency. The well-balanced surface charge (+16.9 mV) of SP34-AB optimizes methanol adsorption and spillover behavior, preventing excessive formaldehyde accumulation and limiting secondary coke-forming reactions. Additionally, the hierarchical porosity introduced via sequential etching enhances mass transfer and reduces diffusion limitations, further suppressing coke formation. SP34-B, modified through basic etching, exhibits a moderate coke formation trend. Its total coke capacity (10.3 %) is slightly lower than that of SP34-AB (10.4 %), yet its RCoke (0.17 mg gcat −1 min−1) is higher, leading to a shorter catalyst lifetime of 600 min. The positive surface potential charge (+22 mV) in SP34-B facilitates methanol spillover and reduces formaldehyde retention, thereby mitigating rapid coke accumulation. However, its relatively lower mesoporosity compared to SP34-AB imposes diffusion limitations that contribute to a faster deactivation rate. The non-etched SAPO-34 (SP34-P) serves as a reference catalyst, with a coke capacity of 11.6 % and an RCoke of 0.21 mg gcat −1 min−1. Consequently, SP34-P undergoes deactivation more rapidly than etched catalyst, with a TOS of 540 min. The lack of hierarchical porosity further exacerbates diffusion limitations, promoting coke accumulation and reducing catalytic stability. Overall, these results demonstrate that while coke capacity remains relatively similar among the samples, the rate of coke formation is significantly influenced by surface charge and structural modifications. The sequential acid-base etched catalyst (SP34-AB) exhibits the most favorable characteristics, with a balanced acidity profile, optimized surface charge, and enhanced mass transfer properties, leading to the slowest coke deposition rate and the longest catalytic lifetime. In contrast, the highly acidic SP34-A experiences the fastest coke accumulation due to excessive formaldehyde retention, whereas SP34-B achieves an intermediate performance by enhancing spillover dynamics but lacking the structural advantages of SP34-AB. These findings highlight the importance of tailored surface charge engineering and hierarchical textural modifications in mitigating coke formation and improving catalyst longevity in the MTO process. 4 Conclusion This study elucidates the fundamental role of surface potential charge in the catalytic behavior of SAPO-34 during the MTO process, demonstrating its influence on methanol adsorption, intermediate stability, and coke formation. The MD simulations and experimental analyses confirm that acidic etching (SP34-A) increases methanol adsorption but restricts spillover, leading to excessive formaldehyde retention and rapid catalyst deactivation. Conversely, basic etching (SP34-B) mitigates coke formation by enhancing spillover dynamics but reduces methanol adsorption capacity. The sequential acid-base modification (SP34-AB) provides an optimal balance by maintaining sufficient adsorption strength while enhancing spillover and diffusion efficiency, minimizing coke deposition, and maximizing light olefin selectivity. The structural modifications induced by sequential etching further contribute to catalyst performance by increasing mesoporosity, reducing crystallite size, and improving mass transfer efficiency. The superior lifetime and selectivity of SP34-AB highlight the advantages of controlled surface charge engineering in SAPO-34 catalysts, offering a promising strategy for improving catalyst stability and efficiency in MTO applications. These findings underscore the necessity of integrating surface potential charge considerations into catalyst design to achieve sustainable and high-performance MTO processes. coredata.dc:description: The methanol-to-olefins (MTO) process over SAPO-34 catalysts is significantly influenced by surface potential charge, affecting methanol adsorption, intermediate spillover, and coke formation. This study investigates the catalytic performance and mechanistic behavior of SAPO-34 catalysts modified through acidic (SP34-A), basic (SP34-B), and sequential acid-base (SP34-AB) etching, with the unmodified SAPO-34 (SP34-P) serving as a reference. The impact of surface potential charge on catalyst performance was examined using molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, NH3-TPD acidity measurements, and zeta potential analysis. The results reveal that a highly negative surface charge (SP34-A, −67 mV) intensifies methanol adsorption but limits spillover efficiency, promoting formaldehyde accumulation and increasing coke deposition, ultimately reducing catalyst lifetime. In contrast, a positive surface charge (SP34-B, +22 mV) enhances spillover and moderates adsorption strength, reducing coke formation and extending catalyst stability. The sequential acid-base etched catalyst (SP34-AB, +16.9 mV) achieves a well-balanced surface charge, optimizing methanol adsorption, spillover behavior, and diffusion efficiency. This balance minimizes secondary reactions, extends catalyst lifetime (586 min, 1.63 times longer than SP34-P), and improves light olefin selectivity (88.82 %), demonstrating the superior catalytic performance of SP34-AB. Structural and textural analysis further confirms that hierarchical porosity, induced via sequential etching, enhances mass transfer and mitigates diffusion limitations, preventing excessive coke formation. These findings establish surface potential charge as a critical parameter in SAPO-34 catalyst design, highlighting sequential acid-base etching as an effective modification strategy to enhance MTO efficiency and catalyst longevity.
